replication_study.hypothesis: Across countries, the Democracy Index (EIU) is positively associated with the total confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million people as of 2020-04-03, controlling for temperature, economic openness, precipitation, and population density.

data_plan.dataset_identifier: COVID replication.dta (compiled cross-country snapshot as of 2020-04-03)
data_plan.source_type: Compiled cross-country database from multiple sources (ECDC, World Bank, EIU, meteoblue/indexmundi)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: Single cross-sectional snapshot; dependent variable is total confirmed cases per million on 2020-04-03
data_plan.access_details: Data file provided in the replication_data folder and expected to be mounted at /app/data inside the container. No special access restrictions for replication.

qualification.explanation: This dataset is directly qualified for replication because it is a compiled cross-country snapshot drawing on the same sources and time point as the original study. It includes the necessary variables (COVID-19 cases as of 2020-04-03, population, annual temperature, trade openness proxies, and the EIU Democracy Index) to operationalize the original regression model.
qualification.similarity_to_original: The original paper uses: ECDC cases, population (2018), yearly average temperature and precipitation, trade openness from World Bank, and Democracy Index from EIU, analyzing a cross-country snapshot on 2020-04-03 (original_paper.pdf summary; post_registration.json data section). The provided dataset includes: COVID_12_31_04_03 (confirmed cases as of 2020-04-03), popData2019 (population), Annual_temp, trade_recent/imputed_trade/trade_2016 (openness measures), and 'Democracy index (EIU)' (replication_data/COVID replication.dta; observed via file header and column names). This matches the sources and variables specified in post_registration.json and the original_paper.pdf summary.
qualification.deviation_from_original: This is a direct replication using the same cross-section and sources (post_registration.json: sample size 163; replication_data file columns indicate the same constructs). The key deviations are analytical: (1) the replication uses robust (HC1) standard errors for OLS to handle heteroscedasticity (original_paper.pdf notes heteroscedasticity); (2) precipitation and population density are included only if present in the dataset; (3) for openness, the script prioritizes 'trade_recent', then 'imputed_trade', then 'trade_2016' based on availability; (4) extended lagged dependent variable models are not implemented unless clearly identifiable lag variables exist (original_paper.pdf describes lagged models, but the provided dataset appears to be a snapshot; no clear time-series panel is present).

data_plan.notes: The dataset file name contains a space ('COVID replication.dta'); the script handles this by searching multiple canonical names in /app/data. Columns include spaces and punctuation (e.g., 'Democracy index (EIU)', 'COVID_12_31_04_03'); the script standardizes column names to snake_case. If a per-million cases variable is not present, the script constructs it as cases per million using COVID_12_31_04_03 and popData2019. If precipitation or population density variables are missing, the model runs without them. The openness measure is chosen among trade_recent, imputed_trade, and trade_2016 depending on availability.

steps: Mount the dataset to /app/data (e.g., copy 'COVID replication.dta' or 'COVID replication.rds' to /app/data).
The script standardizes column names and infers the dependent and independent variables.
Construct the dependent variable as cases per million: COVID_12_31_04_03 / popData2019 × 1e6 if needed.
Select openness variable by priority: trade_recent, then imputed_trade, then trade_2016.
Estimate baseline OLS with robust (HC1) standard errors: cases per million on temperature, openness, democracy, and (if available) precipitation and population density.
Estimate a refined OLS dropping non-significant covariates (p > 0.10) but retaining democracy.
Save outputs: variable_mapping.json, replication_results.json, replication_model_summary.txt to /app/data.
planned_method.models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) with heteroscedasticity-robust (HC1) standard errors; a refined specification drops non-significant covariates while keeping democracy.
planned_method.outcome_variable: Total confirmed COVID-19 cases per one million people (as of 2020-04-03).
planned_method.independent_variables: Yearly average temperature (Annual_temp), economic openness (trade_recent/imputed_trade/trade_2016), democracy index (EIU), plus precipitation and population density if present.
planned_method.control_variables: Precipitation and population density (included if available).
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.10; pandas, numpy, statsmodels, pyreadr (for RDS), pyreadstat (for Stata).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Coefficient on democracy index in the OLS regression of cases per million.
planned_estimation_and_test.test: Two-sided t-test on the democracy coefficient (robust SE), with directional expectation that the coefficient is > 0.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion after coercing relevant columns to numeric.
planned_method.multiple_testing_policy: Not applicable; single focal outcome and coefficient. No multiple-comparison correction.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Primary success if the democracy coefficient is positive and statistically significant at α=0.05 (robust SE). Secondary checks: direction and approximate magnitude relative to original (86.76) and model fit (R²).

files.replicate_democracy_covid.py: Entrypoint Python script placed in replication_data. Reads the dataset from /app/data (supports .dta, .rds, .csv), standardizes column names, constructs the dependent variable if needed, selects openness proxy, and runs OLS with robust SE. Outputs variable_mapping.json, replication_results.json, and a human-readable model summary to /app/data.
files.README_replicate_democracy_covid.txt: Run instructions and notes about expected input file names and column mappings. Not executed.

codebase.notes: All I/O occurs under /app/data. The script prioritizes reading Stata, then RDS, then CSV. It handles non-standard column names by standardizing to snake_case and searching for known variants (Annual_temp, Democracy index (EIU), COVID_12_31_04_03, popData2019, trade_recent/imputed_trade/trade_2016). Robust SE (HC1) are used to address heteroscedasticity noted in the original paper. No GPU or special hardware is required.

analysis.instructions: 1) Place the dataset file (e.g., 'COVID replication.dta') into ./data, which will be mounted to /app/data. 2) Inside the container, run: python /app/replication_data/replicate_democracy_covid.py. 3) Inspect /app/data/replication_results.json and /app/data/replication_model_summary.txt for model estimates and robust p-values. 4) Compare the democracy coefficient and p-value to the original values (coef≈86.76467; p≈0.0001).
analysis.comparison_metrics: Sign and magnitude of the democracy coefficient; robust p-value; adjusted R²; whether democracy remains significant in refined model. Primary benchmark: coefficient positive and statistically significant (p<0.05), direction matching the original claim.
